text:
Activity 1: Energy Sticks

  • Experiment with an energy stick to learn how to activate it.

Try to find three distinct ways to activate the energy stick.

  1. Use more than one person.
  2. Use an object and people.
  3. Use no people at all.
Drag and drop the following tile into your workspace and answer the questions:

Activity 1 Questions:

  • Can you find the limit of the number of people that can activate the energy stick?
  • How did the energy stick behave as more people were added?
  • Were there any materials that wouldn’t work to activate the energy stick?
  • Which materials DID work to activate the energy stick?

The materials you used to activate the energy sticks conduct electricity. However, each material provides some measure of resistance. The materials that didn’t conduct electricity were excellent resistors, but all materials resist the flow of current to some extent. In a later module, you will use standardized resistors to help control the flow of electricity.
Activity 2: Build a circuit with varying resistance

Step 1: Build a basic circuit

Given a 9V battery, an LED light, and two alligator clips, , work with your group to figure out how to turn on the light. 

An LED is like a lightbulb, but it works a little differently.  The power source should be connected to the anode (longer side). This is also the place where the current will enter the LED.
Step 3: Test the varible resistor with the LED

First connect your 2 alligator clips to the 9V (one on each pole), then connect the negative clip to the negative lead of the LED, and finally, bend the positive lead of the LED (anode, the longest) so it's easy to move on the paper and it gives good contact.

Now that you have your assembly, touch one end of the band with the other alligator clip and the LED lead on the other end of the graphite band and slowly make the 2 connections closer and closer to see what happens... (*IMPORTANT* Avoid touching the LED lead directly on the battery pole or you can burn it up! You can also add a resistor in the circuit to avoid any damage of this kind) Explanation: The reason why the LED is glowing is because the current from the positive pole of the battery (Black clip) flows through the graphite band and completes the circuit to the LED; result, the LED is glowing. Now the reason why the LED gets brighter when you get the black clip nearest is because the graphite has some resistance (Doesn't conduct electricity perfectly). So the closer you get to the LED, the less resistance the graphite  provides, so more current goes to the LED and makes it brighter!

Try a wider or longer graphite  band or try other patterns and see what happens! Try with other conductors like metals or anything else you know! Try coloring lighter or darker for different results! Record the results of your experimentation in your workspace.
